content.description: A very fun climb that follows the obvious line up the middle of the crack/chimney. Pull the initial reachy bulge to get started, enjoy easier ground through the middle, and then work through the last tricky bit of stemming before you clip the chains.
content.location: Starts in a wide crack with a faint "790" visible written on the rock in large lettering.  About 10 ft right of a large tree growing leaning away from the cliff.

content.description: Right side of the wall immediately to the left of the very low angle slab routes. Techy vertical climbing on small but positive holds to a very balancy crux.

Starts on a well featured vertical face and climbs a series of small bulges.  Most of the climbing is easier, but one big move over a pretty featureless bulge will present some difficulties, especially to those with limited reach.  Easier climbing to the top.

 "My first time was fun, but I wish it had been longer and I was able to do a few more moves when it was hard."
content.location: About 50 yards to the right as you approach the cliff from the road.  Follows the buttress between two large crack systems (that are Silver Streaks and End of Poison Ivy).

content.description: A fun full-length route that takes you to the top of the cliff. A nice variety of climbing moves with a few thought provoking sequences along the way.
content.location: Far right side of the Katz Wall, just right of the large crack system that is "The End of Poison Ivy"

content.description: Vertical climbing on good but small crimps to start, followed by some thought-provoking moves up top on slopers.  Don't blow it trying to clip the chains.  If getting on it early in the season, convince your buddy to climb it first and brush off the finish hold for you.
Follows an angling crack up a slab.
content.location: Obvious slab route with large holds.

content.description: Another easy line with big holds and fun movement.  Start in the large crack, then follow the jugs through the steep stuff.  Can finish straight up staying next to the big crack, or move left into the flake to go to the upper set of anchors.  Great kids/beginners route.
content.location: Right of the two slab jugs line.

content.description: Climb the vertical face to a good-sized roof/bulge.  Finding the right holds and a little technique keeps the difficulty at it's suggested grade.This route was bolted with it's neighbor to the left in the dead of winter.   The developer kept the cold at bay with some "Hot Stuff" whiskey.
content.location: About the middle of the Katz Wall, to the right of the low-angle ramp (that is "Katz in the Cradle") and left of a large off-width (that is "Dusty Squeeze").Starts just left of a large tree growing right at the base of the cliff.

content.description: A previously bolted route that's really a trad route.  This thing eats gear and the placements are just downright fun.Starts in a large flaring off-width, although you can also start on the face immediately to the right (steeper, but on good holds).  Stem and chimney your way to the top.  Continue past an old rap anchor to the top for a cruxy but rewarding finish and the real anchors at the top of the cliff. Enjoy the well-deserved view!So much fun!Note that if you are expecting to find some old bolts still in place, you'll have to trust your cams I'm afraid. The bolts have been pulled.
content.protection: Everything from stoppers to micro-cams to a #3.  Bolted anchors
content.location: Far left side of the Poison Ivy Wall (Every wondered why it's called the Poison Ivy Wall?  There isn't any PI you say!  Well, not anymore.  There was a time when you couldn't even see rock it was so thick... from top to bottom, left to right.  The entire cave and the wall above it were coated.  Trees of poison ivy, vines as thick as my arm, I kid you not!

content.description: Great off width! Very fun with great placements. Start in the OW with good pro or climb the 5.7 face to the right with no pro to the first ledge. After the small tree mid route squeeze your way and stem up the crack. To finish, top out with a well protected but thought provoking crux. Bolted anchors in place.
content.protection: Standard rack, but 5s and 6s would be great although it’s doable without them, set of nuts and some slings for natural pro if your into that sort of thing.
content.location: This route is the crack to the left of  Silver Streak(5.9). It has a small tree growing out of it 20’ up.

content.description: Start just right of a broad shield and work your way up a vertical face.  Stand on a ledge, set up and pull through the cruxy bulge up top.This route and it's neighbor to the right were bolted in the dead of winter.   There was a steady stream of water dripping down on the developer making it a pretty wet and miserable.  However, some imbibing of "Hot Stuff" whiskey left the developer comfortably numb.
content.location: About the middle of the Katz Wall, to the right of the low-angle ramp (that is "Katz in the Cradle") and left of a large off-width (that is "Dusty Squeeze").  Starts just left of a large tree growing right at the base of the cliff.  You'll find some large concrete slabs in the trail near the base.

content.description: Climb through a series a bulges, some easy, some hard.  The last one will likely give you pause and require a pretty good reach. Take it all the way to the top on some easy but insecure slab.
content.location: On a buttress/bulge between two very large crack systems.  Between Silver Streaks and My First Time.

content.description: Start in a large water runnel under the crack, stemming and chimney up the crack using large face holds on both sides.
content.protection: Gear from #2 to #4 or 5. Bolted anchors.
content.location: Right end of Katz Wall, in the large crack right of Katz Corner.

content.description: This area includes a wide variety of difficulties, styles and rock types. On the anchors of every route there are a pair of mussy hooks. Very important:  only use the hooks to lower the LAST climber in your party.  Please do NOT climb on top rope through the hooks. If more than one person is climbing the route, always clip your rope through your own quickdraws to the anchors.  Then, once everybody in your party has climbed the route, the last climber simply needs to clip the rope through the hooks, remove your draws, and be lowered.  (Anchor cleaning and rappelling is not best practice and is much more likely to lead to an accident.) The slab climbs on the left end (Katz Out of the Bag and Scaredy Katz) are both pretty tricky, but high quality, though they tend to be wet in winter and early spring.  At 10+, Katz Out of the Bag is really a total sandbag... but an outstanding climbing.The next two routes, Katz Corner and Katz in the Cradle, between a low-angle ramp feature and a large crack system, make for great beginner routes or for top-roping with kids.  Usually dry except during or right after heavy rain.The next two routes start on a vertical wall with thin features before pulling a substantial roof.  Good fun.  These are newer lines and have fragile rock, so beware that rock may continue to break for a little while here!  These dry out relatively quickly.The next section include five routes that all go the top of the cliff-line and are "full length" -- two trad lines and three sport lines.  All are quite good, although in very different ways! The sport routes tend to dry out quickly year round, but the trad routes stay wet most of the winter and spring and may need a bit of regular spring clean-up due to runoff and debris.
